events.target_title: Feature Request: Clickable Area in List View

note.body:
Oh I see, I am on linux Mint 19.2 and the available Nautilus version is 1:3.26.4-0, so maybe that is why I can't see those options.

Nonetheless, I would argue that having some blank area, maybe left of the icons, would make the user experience more consistent. One would simply always use right click instead of facing several different workflows to achieve the same thing.

1) Icon View, whatever number of files -> can right-click between icons
2) List View, not many files in window -> can right click below list
3) List View, too many files in window -> must use alternative option button

I understand that there are probably hundreds of more urgent issues to be addressed, but I think a lot of users would greatly benefit from this problem being addressed, especially when working in the file manager is a very frequent action.

Thank you very much.

events.target_title: Generating Voice Over files
Generating Voice Over files

note.body:
Voice Over is a TTS feature presented in different Apple products. The version used in iPods uses the ID3-Tags of audio files and generates an artificial voice to read them out loud. Using this, the iPod Shuffle 4G can be navigated, even without any display. 

Here is the wikipedia article to the general [Voice Over](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VoiceOver), which is also featured in more products than the iPod.

The script uses eSpeak or picoSpeaker to generate the audio files

> That's the intent of this PR. It makes deprecation explicit to everyone by logging a helpful message. 

In most of case yes, i agree that is the right way to do it, but in the case of a Cinnamon is not just the code of the shell, they also maintain by him self the extensions as part of. So this will spamming the logs instead of create a helpful message.

> Regarding Cinnamon, I'm sure they're watching.

Who was watching before is not part of linuxmint anymore. So, i don't think there are some one watching it right now.

> They have their own fork so if they don't want to deprecate Mainloop they don't have to. 

Cinnamon can now run directly with gjs because recently was incorporate in gjs all the Cinnamon different code to make this possible.  I think that forgetting this and create again a difference would be an step back in that regard.

It depend on how you see it. If you are a Cinnamon developers you will see that you need to migrate a lot of code in a short period of time and you will conclude again that is better have your own fork just for that, than line up with the gjs code.

Is convenient for a language like gjs that people fork it or that people used it?

events.target_title: Consider supporting AppIndicators by default (instead of a non-default extension)

note.body:
> We will surely need consensus from KDE for this to be successful, though, or we'll wind up with app menus 2.0. 

I know about the good intention that is behind have just only one solution in a consensus, but if this intention fail, please don't desist of your original idea. 

As a replace, an idea could be implemented something like [this](https://phabricator.kde.org/D10461), but in this case it will be to swap from the DBusMenu to the GMenu model instead of what KDE create. That idea can also be used to reuse the current implementation of the StatusNotifier API. So, using an idea like that can add right now a lot of application to the new GNOME API, without need to wait for a change on that applications that currently only support the KDE way of the AppIndicator.

Also KDE can use again his original idea but now to support the new GNOME API for AppIndicators instead of only used it for the Global Menus that comes from the Gtk applications.

The problem that i see with the proposed solution is that have a performance implication, because is needed convert one representation to the other, but i think it's a little implication if we compare it with do nothing and i think finally both will win GNOME and KDE, because at less will be an alternative to reuse the work of the other without give up each own API.

I also want to shared some comments as someone that implemented a client of the DBusMenu API and the DBus-GMenu API in gjs:

The DBusMenu use an identifier (id) for the menu items, while in the GMenu model is suggested that this attribute (the id) could be omitted as is not "standard". I find pretty useful to have an identifier in the GMenu API as an "standard" attribute. This is because have an id will ensure to us have a way to compare menu items on a Menu layout updates and this will help to reused the same clutter actors. So, we don't need to delete one MenuItem actor and then create another when is the same real MenuItem, as we can reuse the same actor that Mutter know already how to paint. 

After measure it for the performance point of view, I can say that on a big menu, the difference of have a mechanism to reused the MenuItem actors, its noticeable in comparative to not have that mechanism.

events.target_title: Implement the "taking out the garbage" scheme and remove the Big Hammer

note.body:
> Find out how to get some statistics on the memory usage of gnome-shell over time, and the number of objects kept alive in gnome-shell, and compare the results before and after this fix.

I hope this related projects can help to create something more in concordance with the requirements of that point:

1. Use the Gnome3 - Looking Glass:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/master/js/ui/lookingGlass.js

2. An extension that use the Gnome3 - Looking Glass:
https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/476/looking-glass-inspector/

3. A cinnamon extension that observed the memory and apply a garbage collection when it grow up to a maximum allowed number (that was make by me some time ago):
https://gitlab.com/lestcape/Garbage-Collector/

4. The Cinnamon project called Melange (the Cinnamon - Looking Glass) that is a fork of the Gnome3 - Looking Glass. It can have more features that can be also relevant:
https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon/tree/master/files/usr/share/cinnamon/cinnamon-looking-glass

5. Michel (a Mint developer) created an extension for the Cinnamon desktop that use a different mechanism to monitor the memory that use a process with gtop:
https://github.com/mtwebster/Cinnamonitor

events.target_title: Create overall plan for extensions reboot

note.body:
I will add what i considered that can improved the extension developers experience.

1. A session on https://discourse.gnome.org/ will probably help.

2. Provide facilities for developers it's good, but also warranty independence in the develop or GNOME will finally ending eating the project. That means:
     *  Suggest the best way to install extensions, but not force to be **only** in this way. So, don't integrate developers by force. Add features that will be an incentive to the developers to be joined to gnome.gitlab, but **never** restrict the installation of extensions to be only possible using gnome.gitlab.

     * Do not impose commits to the developers. It's always preferable negate the possibility to use the platform than force the developers to do an update without his approval. So, only the developer of the extension will can have the power to merge the requests of the extension where he/she is the maintainer. Ensure that no one that was not explicit selected by the developer of that extension will have the power to merge a request, not matter how "important" that could be to the users or to any organization or partner of GNOME.

3. Detect points in commons between extension and create a facility at the level of the shell to integrate the extensions without enter in conflicts. That means as examples:
     *  If exist extensions that want to add panels in different desktop locations, please create a shell API that handled panel in different locations. Never let extensions fight each other for a place in a side of the screen. Let then know the existing panels and basic features that a panel have in an official way. Avoid repeat the same code to create panels that only will conflicts one with the another.
     *  Same of the case of panels, but for PanelsButton. Ensure that extensions will not fight each other for a place in a panel. This also means ensure that the user will have the PanelButton in the position that he want.
     *  Add a role API to detect conflicts between extensions. So, extensions that implements some roles in commons can be prevented to be installed until the user uninstall the others that implemented the same role(s).

4. Try to find a better way to avoid gsettings conflicts between sessions. Help the extension developers to prevent conflicts between GNOME sessions. In Desktops like Ubuntu the users can have several different sessions where to install the same extensions. Modify a settings option in one session actually means modify a settings option in all sessions at same time. But this is in most of cases an unwanted behaviour.

6. Avoid connect signals in the shell that can not be disconnected. Always provide in all connections made, the connection id to the extension developer to be disable in the case they want.

7. Do not force GUI artifact by default in the shell. Avoid complex method that can be fail to disable default desktop features. I'm talking about:

```javascript
    'activities': ActivitiesButton,
    'aggregateMenu': AggregateMenu,
    'appMenu': AppMenuButton,
    'dateMenu': imports.ui.dateMenu.DateMenuButton,
    'a11y': imports.ui.status.accessibility.ATIndicator,
    'keyboard': imports.ui.status.keyboard.InputSourceIndicator,
    'dwellClick': imports.ui.status.dwellClick.DwellClickIndicator,
```

8. Avoid monkey patching providing the necessary shell API and avoiding the shell examples of monkey patching inside the default shell extensions. This is because people use that code to learn how to do the things. Let the developers of the extensions a place to report the monkey patch that they already use. With that will be possible considered create an API for that functionality inside the shell in a future and then avoid conflicts.

9. Promote the avoid the reuse of a code when is not needed or the code is unstable. Is always preferable repeat a code in an extension that the usage of something that can dramatically change in the future and break the extension. This probably can be done adding the words **Unstable API** at the begin of the class as a comment.

10. Use user reports to disable problematic extension automatically. In my opinion this is much more effective that any revision. More that 3 reports to an extension make by different users will disable the extension installation and probably can be created an API to also alert the user that already have the extension about this report.

11. After a shell crash provide provide to the user an option to disable the specific extension that cause the crash if is some how know or to disable all extensions in other case.

12. Provide to the user a way to easy detect extensions that potentially have problems, like can be memory leaks (cheeking the overall ram that is used by the shell process in the time) or know sync calls that can slowdown the compositor thread (like can be spawn_sync).

13. Please try to isolate extension for the compositor thread, to avoid a general crash. Specially in the Wayland session. It's a lot of work create a new process outside Mutter where the extension can be run, but it's in my opinion the best way and probably the only one effective way to warranty much more stability as a whole. The shell need to be better always and this means API and ABI breaks for the extensions what inevitably means extensions crashes that can also crash the shell. This also is a much more effective way to avoid conflict that any revision process.

14. A better shell, means better extensions. Always there are much more to do for all sides, is not just better extensions is also a better shell for that extensions, because at the end one thing means the another.

events.target_title: Create overall plan for extensions reboot

note.body:
@sri I'm not against to have a centralized platform. I'm only against provide ONLY this possibility for to install extensions. Both aproximations are radically different.

But more over, i think that you can not avoid the possibility to install extensions in a different way of the default,  also if you really-really want that. This is because just the fact that extensions exist means that some one else can create an extension that allow to install extensions in a different way. So, my point is that is preferable that this some one will be also GNOME, instead of an external develop that will create more problem that what will solved for sure.

Also please note that you will have the problem of resolve how developers will install and test an extension that only can be installed from gnome.gitlab. If only will be possible install extensions from gnome.gitlab, the process of develop an extension will be dramatically difficult and i think this is not your intention but the opposite of it. 

So, i think that you are worried about explaining things to me for nothing. This is because i think is not convenient and possible to have just one way to install extensions not matter if this is affecting users or the GNOME reputation for thing that GNOME really can not controlled. Limit this is not just worse, is impossible to GNOME. So, be flexible is in that case better in my opinion.

events.target_title: Create overall plan for extensions reboot

note.body:
> There are no plans to change where extensions are installed from. Extensions will continue to be installed from extensions.gnome.org or GNOME Software. 

Sorry if I mention something that you never considered change. I'm just sharing what i think, I can't guess what will result here. So, i mention what i considered a good or what is to me a wrong direction. Also i don't need to have the reason, is just my opinion.

As a more big expiation:

You can manually install extensions today, just copying it to the right place or executing some few commands or also with a bash script like [this example](https://github.com/RabbitHols/Unity-on-Gnome/blob/master/installer.sh). Some people distribute the extension also with a bash script to be installed inside the extension. This can be a [make file](https://gitlab.com/LinxGem33/Arc-Menu/blob/master/Makefile) or a [meson](https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/ShellExtensions/desktop-icons/blob/master/meson.build)

So, one target of the new rebooted project can be avoid that type of installations, because they are not secured and can be the cause of conflict and more unwanted things, that you already mention that this project will help to fix, that is true. How I don't know then if one of the targets of the project will be prevent that type of insecure installation, allowing only the installations that come from from the new more secure mechanism.

**My point is then:**  Please, don't try to prevent this other types of installation as they are also useful. That is all. Hope that is more clear now :).

events.target_title: Fix memory leak in xmlParseBalancedChunkMemoryRecover
Fix memory leak in xmlParseBalancedChunkMemoryRecover

note.body: When doc is not NULL, newDoc->oldNs = doc->oldNs(created by caller), so set newDoc->oldNS = NULL in the end is ok. When doc is NULL, xmlParseBalancedChunkMemoryRecover->xmlParseContent->xmlParseElement->xmlParseStartTag->xmlSAX2StartElement->xmlSAX2AttributeInternal->xmlSearchNs->xmlTreeEnsureXMLDecl will create a new xmlNs and bind to doc(newDoc)->oldNs, we need to free it in xmlFreeDoc, in this case, if we set newDoc->oldNs = NULL before xmlFreeDoc in xmlParseBalancedChunkMemoryRecover, we leak the created xmlNS.

events.target_title: failure to write gps altitude in image file

note.body:
Hi Jens Georg !

It is very strange, it took me quite some time to track it down and the exclude other bugs in my script.

Please find here my very simple testing script:

====================

```python
from gi import require_version
require_version('GExiv2', '0.10')
from gi.repository import GExiv2

def reverse(path_file):
  
    
    metadata = GExiv2.Metadata(path_file)
 
    lat=metadata.get_gps_latitude()
    lon=metadata.get_gps_longitude()
    elevation=metadata.get_gps_altitude()
    print "BEFORE", lat, lon, elevation
    
    true_elevation=2200
    print "TARGET", true_elevation
    metadata.set_gps_info(lon, lat, true_elevation)
    metadata.save_file()

    metadata = GExiv2.Metadata(path_file)
 
    lat=metadata.get_gps_latitude()
    lon=metadata.get_gps_longitude()
    elevation=metadata.get_gps_altitude()
    print "AFTER", lat, lon, elevation


    return

 
if __name__ == "__main__":
    reverse("test.jpg")
```



If I target an elevation of 2100 the altitude is changed in the metadata successfully:

runfile('/home/georg/scripts/geo_reverse/test2.py', wdir='/home/georg/scripts/geo_reverse')
BEFORE 46.39762875 7.61539789806 -2147.483648
TARGET 2100
AFTER 46.39762875 7.61539789778 2100.0

If the target is 2200 the altitude is reversed back to the old negative altitude. I do not even know where this old figure could come from.

runfile('/home/georg/scripts/geo_reverse/test2.py', wdir='/home/georg/scripts/geo_reverse')
BEFORE 46.39762875 7.61539789778 2100.0
TARGET 2200
AFTER 46.39762875 7.6153978975 -2147.483648

I include the test jpg.

events.target_title: Zip the documents

note.body:
After all these pro and cons I only see cons:
* Compression of jpegs, cpu usage, slower program
* complexity
* harder to `$find` with paperwork and also with external tools
* zips have their own index

I propose to close this issue.

I could think of a database or a central json to store all labels, keywords and maybe also all texts of all files, then you would only need to store the jpgs from the scans. This file should be in the RAM completely to allow quick changes. The writing to disk could run in a background task without blocking the GUI/next commands.

events.target_title: Maps claims to be offline when behind proxy

note.body:
Same problem as @denics - Debian 10 and Maps 3.30.3. In addition to my wifi icon having a question mark, although all other applications using internet work fine, and saying it's offline, there is a problem with window focus, for example no cursor appears when I click on the search bar, and every letter I type is repeated twice, very weird (might be an unrelated issue, like #129 Wayland). I recorded a small screencast: https://peertube.social/videos/watch/d881662c-80d2-48de-aef5-6725f8434735

__Edit__ I found that

    $ nmcli g
    STATE                  CONNECTIVITY  WIFI-HW  WIFI     WWAN-HW  WWAN     
    connected (site only)  limited       enabled  enabled  enabled  disabled 

And playing around with random network manager commands I finally saw

    $ nmcli networking connectivity check
    full

I don't know what caused this change, perhaps it was just _calling_ that last command? Anyway, now that connectivity is reported as full, the Maps application comes up correctly, also keyboard and mouse work correctly now (mouse pan and zoom only works, when I start from the terminal with `export GDK_BACKEND=wayland`).

events.target_title: color temperature - original temperature confused with intended temperature

note.body:
Sorry, but I don't agree that this feature can be said to work as intended. Maybe it would be confusing to change it now because people got used to the bug, but a bug it is.

If you look up any source on color temperatures, you will see that daylight is roughly around 6000 K and indoor light is roughly around 3000 K. Therefore the following behaviour will be expected by anyone not used to the bug:

* To make the colours of an indoor photo match those of a daylight photo of the same object, you need to set 'original temperature' to something in the indoor range (near 3000 K) and the 'intended temperature' to something in the daylight range (near 6000 K).
*  To make the colours of a daylight photo match those of an indoor photo of the same object, you need to set 'original temperature' to something in the daylight range (near 6000 K) and the 'intended temperature' to something in the indoor range (near 3000 K).

But this is not how the feature currently works. If you try this, you will see that the colour differences will get much worse, with the first photo looking as if taken under a red lamp and the second as if taken under a blue lamp. However, if you swap input and output, things work as expected (although you obviously need to tweak the temperatures for perfect results).

This is why I am pretty sure that input and output temperature are swapped.

events.target_title: dy and dx is not handled correctly for text and tspan
Appication crashes when trying ot import XML file
Can't copy text from location field in read-only calendar
Screen curtain is unnatural and unnecessary on desktop: please provide option to disable
Screen curtain is unnatural and unnecessary on desktop: please provide option to disable

note.body:
I know that you can use escape, and I know that you can also just start typing your password.  That's all fine, but it doesn't change the fact that for users with a mouse and users *used* to using a mouse, having to click and drag is counterintuitive, unnecessary, and a regression versus previous behaviour, where just nudging the mouse would invite them to enter their password (or bring back their desktop).

The computer *knows* that the user wants the login screen, but rather than providing that, it instructs users to click and drag using visual language that is expressed in terms of mobile 'phones and finger swiping.  The pulsing arrows at the bottom of the screen do not in any way convey a sense of clicking and dragging: instead they invoke incomprehension and despair.  There is no need to demand a click-and-drag: why the extra effort when logging in/revealing the desktop is the only meaningful response?

Think of someone less technology-literate, used to the way their computer has behaved for thirty years: you nudge the mouse and the machine wakes up, either showing you your desktop or inviting you to log in/type in your password.

The visual design language, the extra effort for a routine task, all of this is forcing an unnecessary and inappropriate tablet/smartphone metaphor onto desktop users.

To what end?  How does this benefit us?

events.target_title: Clears copy buffer on exit (paste doesn't work after closing evolution)
Clipboard (copy-and-paste) Wayland→Wayland or Wayland→X11 from closed applications is broken

note.body:
Been rolled out into Debian buster, which defaults to Wayland.  Really disrupts normal use.

Since it looks as if there's more important stuff in the queue (reported 3 years ago!), I wonder is there a workaround, like is there a clipboard manager or something which fixes this in the meantime?

events.target_title: Screen curtain is unnatural and unnecessary on desktop: please provide option to disable

note.body:
All I'm asking for is an option to disable this feature.

When a computer knows what I want to do and tells me "no, do it this, different, new, less obvious, *harder*, way" I think the design process has maybe stumbled a little bit.

events.target_title: Sorting direction icons are misleading

note.body:
For the time column the reason to interpret down-pointing arrow as from most recent to oldest ( descending time ) can be explained if we think to the time as an **absolute** measurement.

This way we can say that a recent file is bigger in time than an older and should appears before because in absolute time measurement is greather.

The same reasoning can work for human too, and we can say that a 1 year old person surely born in a date bigger than a 40 year old person.

I agree with you that there is something lacks about *recenteusness* of a file ( eg. modified 1 hour ago ) but "Modified" here is displaying an absolute time so we should eventually introduce either a new column type to handle that in non ambiguous manner (eg. "Modified (rel)") and/or an option to allow the user to choose column Time mangement ( if absolute or relative ).

More in this case a "Modified (rel)" should use human like representation displaying "5 secs ago", "1 week ago", etc.. so this could disambiguate at view what we are meanining.

The only way to disambiguate and use only one column type "Modified" should to make it larger displaying that human interpret ( eg. "16:36 (40min ago)" ) may using a view preference option Abs/Rel time and in this case we can safely sort with up-pointing arrow to find recent file on the top.

After all personally I just prefer an absolute time view because it's just a convention not so difficult to acquire and use. For sure there is the need to choose a clear and coincise representation if we want to allow a user in ability to choose which mental model to use, because as stated from @kakserpom there are already all other representations all with an absolute time meaning that have become a standard de facto.

```
❯ cat touchpad-t480-sensitivity.patch 
diff --git a/src/evdev-mt-touchpad-gestures.c b/src/evdev-mt-touchpad-gestures.c
index 4a0287c7..6f803533 100644
--- a/src/evdev-mt-touchpad-gestures.c
+++ b/src/evdev-mt-touchpad-gestures.c
@@ -605,6 +605,8 @@ tp_gesture_handle_state_scroll(struct tp_dispatch *tp, uint64_t time)

 	/* scroll is not accelerated */
 	delta = tp_filter_motion_unaccelerated(tp, &raw, time);
+	delta.x *= 0.4;
+	delta.y *= 0.4;

 	if (normalized_is_zero(delta))
 		return GESTURE_STATE_SCROLL;

```

events.target_title: Failed to obtain access token / OAuth-2FA error

note.body:
Figured it out! I had my Azure application set to Web API instead of a Native Client.

![azure-evolution](/uploads/19f8e1b0db02388d846184d3dd6df1bd/azure-evolution.png)

After that, I was able to authentication/get an OAuth token. 

Additionally, some [other](https://github.com/Azure-Samples/active-directory-dotnetcore-devicecodeflow-v2#register-the-client-app-active-directory-dotnet-deviceprofile), [issues](https://github.com/AzureAD/azure-activedirectory-library-for-cordova/issues/180#issuecomment-437824805) also led me to set `oauth2AllowImplicitFlow` and `allowPublicClient` to true, although I'm not sure if that's necessary.

There is no mention of IMAP/SMTP configuration, though I know for a fact that outlook.office365.com supports IMAP/SMTP. (There is an element called `AutoDiscoverSMTPAddress`, but it just contains my address).

@mjog here is my suggestion for how to proceed, tell me if you find it sensible: whenever there's an Outlook EWS account, we just try to connect to IMAP/SMTP with the credentials and the server provided by GOA.

We could add the result of this query to the POX autodiscover as debug information in case of failure. If this sounds reasonable, I'll try to code this up :)

events.target_title: Support native connection to MS Exchange servers

note.body:
I found this MS documentation page:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/clients-and-mobile-in-exchange-online/pop3-and-imap4/pop3-and-imap4
Interestingly, it says that IMAP and SMTP are enabled by default for all Exchange users. As opposed to what they write though, `outlook.office365.com` also serves as an SMTP server, so we could use it in both settings if that's ok.

The program I wrote makes a POST request to `https://autodiscover.example.com/autodiscover/autodiscover.xml` following the POX instructions. It follows the redirect, which in my case is to `https://autodiscover-s.outlook.com/autodiscover/autodiscover.xml`, then displays the result of the request as I posted previously.

So I'd say we can still use autodiscover, follow the redirects, and setup IMAP/SMTP with the same address of the Exchange server, which should support them by default. If this fails then we give users the ability to manually set the IMAP/SMTP configuration. Sounds good?

note.body:
@ellestone 

I asked for the implementation of xdg-desktop-portal support. I'm not interested in a "new" GIMP-specific way in thinking of files. I just like to edit images, and comfortable safe them again. Why does every App reinvent the reel again? 

There are may requests, form may users @ GTK+ to improve the file dialogue. But nothing happens since years. Do you understand the frustration? 

@Jehan 

xdg-desktop-portal would be the grate option to offer everyone the file dialogue they link. 

I think it doesn't matter what I like or not.

But our costumers (we do scientific software) are working with many different DE/Distros/OS. Most of them aren't Gnome users. We advice to process images our software exports, in GIMP. We have got many requests because of the very unorthodox GTK+ file dialogue. (not only in GIMP) People are used to Apple and/or Windows dialogues. We can't change this fact. 

xdg-desktop-portal would work around this issue.

note.body:
Regarding the version of the librsvg pixbuf loader, on my particular system (Ubuntu 19.04) I have installed (although I don't know if Firefox or Chromium might bundle their own):

* libgdk-pixbuf2.0-0 - GDK Pixbuf library
* librsvg2-2 - SAX-based renderer library for SVG files (runtime)
* librsvg2-common - SAX-based renderer library for SVG files (extra runtime)

When I looked at the logic behind the bug, I was looking at the master branch of the code mirrored on Github.

Thanks for the suggestion. I installed the latest Ubuntu version I could find (2.44.14-1) which is later than the one you said a fix was made in (2.44.12):
https://packages.ubuntu.com/eoan/librsvg2-2

`sudo dpkg -i librsvg2-2_2.44.14-1_amd64.deb`

I rebooted (just to be sure) and Chrome and Firefox still crash the same way.

events.target_title: Buffer overrun crash for certain file content when file selected in a File Opener

note.body:
Upgrading to librsvg2-common_2.44.14-1 fixed the crashing issue in Firefox and Chromium. Thanks.

==== More details

That command from before only updated the one specific deb file I downloaded. 

So, to test your hypothesis, I downloaded and installed the librsvg2-common package for the Ubuntu eoan release from: https://packages.ubuntu.com/eoan/librsvg2-common

`sudo dpkg -i librsvg2-common_2.44.14-1_amd64.deb`

I can confirm that change has apparently fixed the issue. I can now select the files that previously crashed Chrome or Firefox when selected and the applications do not crash anymore (once they were closed and reopened to use the new version of the library).

Thank you for your time looking into this and figuring out a workaround, Federico.

One remaining question is whether there is any security risk -- from improperly processing files using the older version of the library -- that merits distributions like Ubuntu upgrading the library sooner rather than later? If not, then you can mark this issue resolved and no longer confidential.
